RHS student Praket Nigam spent his summer and his own savings creating care packages for hospital staff and volunteers, an initiative he called “Happy and Helpful Packages by Praket.” In honor of his grandmother who advocated for social justice in India, Praket purchased the supplies and assembled gift bags to be donated to seven hospitals: Valley Hospital, St. Joseph’s University Medical Center, Bergen New Bridge Medical Center, Good Samaritan Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Care, Joseph M. Sanzari Children’s Hospital and Mount Sinai Morningside. Each package was adorned with a white flower, a favorite of his grandmother.

Thank you, Praket, for your kindness and generosity to our healthcare heroes. #FridayFeature

The district named Dr. Jean Schoenlank, Principal of Ridge School, as the recipient of this year's Ashby Award. Congratulations, Dr. Schoenlank!

The ceremony can be viewed at the following link: https://rhs.ridgewood.k12.nj.us/our_school/about_us/rhs_live_stream

Thank you for your cooperation.

Community Mobile COVID-19 Testing (for those with or without symptoms) will be held on Monday, June 22, 2020 at the Graydon Pool Parking Lot.

ALL MOBILE TESTING SITES ARE WEATHER PERMITTING. In case of inclement weather, please visit www.co.bergen.nj.us for details.

Residents should bring:

-Identification (driver’s license/ID card, social security card, passport, or birth certificate)
-Proof of Bergen County Residency or Employment with municipal or county government (copy of lease, driver’s license, or utility bill)

Saliva COVID-19 Test: Please do not eat, drink, smoke, or chew gum 30 minutes before arrival.

COVID-19 Antibody Test: Antibody testing priority will be given to Bergen County first responders, healthcare workers, and Bergen County residents who had a prior COVID-19 positive diagnostic test and who bring a copy of their test results.

Calling all movie lovers! Have you seen the incredible work of our middle school students in the 2020 GW/BF Film Festival?

Hosted by Mr. Luts and Mr. Ordini, the film festival showcases work from both Ridgewood middle schools and is usually held each June at the Bow Tie Cinemas Warner Theatre in downtown Ridgewood. This year, of course, the film festival had to move the show online, and it debuted on June 2nd on YouTube. While nothing compares to the experience of seeing a film on the big screen, the silver lining is that the YouTube page has gotten more than 3,000 views in comparison to the 180 viewers typically present in the audience at the theatre. Wow!

The GW/BF Film Festival remains one of the best judged Middle School film festivals in the Northeast. Judges include entertainment industry professionals from The New Yorker, MTV Networks, ABC digital and GW 6th grade science teacher, Mr. Wondra.

Congratulations to all of our young filmmakers!

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9ItLmItVGC65q89K8sDgTA

Ridgewood High School students Yurina and Mayuna Homma spent their free time over the past month making 1,000 origami cranes (senbazuru) to donate to Valley Hospital to lift the spirits of both the hospital workers and the patients who are fighting COVID-19. “Senbazuru comes from a Japanese legend, and there are many beliefs behind it. Some say that it represents peace, and others say it is a good luck charm for quickly recovering from illness or injury. My sister and I actually made one for my grandmother when she was fighting cancer, and she loved it. We figured that this will be a perfect way to cheer up our heroes,” explained Yurina.

To read the press release, visit the district website at https://www.ridgewood.k12.nj.us/our_district/office_of_the_superintendent/press_releases

Our K-12 music staff is going strong during this period of remote learning and continuing to advance music education in the district, using creative ways to connect with students and bring music into Ridgewood homes.

When asked to reflect upon the importance of music education, Ridgewood High School Band Director, Jeffrey Haas said, “Great music education reminds us that schools are places where we must care for children and nurture their spirits, creativity, passion and compassion. It reminds us that we are not a nation of data, but one of thinkers, creators and innovators; that we suffer defeats and tragedies; and that we can rise from these setbacks to face each day courageously. Great music education reminds us that we are still human.”

#BestCommunitiesforMusicEducation

(Not pictured - Jason Curcio and Stephen Polanin)

Career Pathways in Medicine students are studying cancer and cancer treatments. Ms. Kunzle invited fellow teacher, Ms. Fleming, to join her Zoom session with the class to share her experience with surgery, chemotherapy, and cancer drug trials.

Ms. Fleming happily joined as a guest speaker and had this to say about the experience. "It was awesome to speak to the CPM class yesterday. I really miss interacting with students, and it was great to have a chance to tell them a little bit about this rare cancer. My hope is always to raise awareness about rare sarcomas and to inspire these students who are interested in careers in medicine to pursue further study in oncology."

We are so appreciative of Ms. Fleming's willingness to motivate and encourage our students in their journey to become health care professionals. Thank you, Ms. Fleming! You are a true gift as an educator.

Benjamin Franklin Middle School students Maiah Riedel and Emily Scharfenberg won Middle School Best Film at the Count Basie Teen and College Film Fest 2020 for their documentary, Unbridled. The two student filmmakers have been active members of the BFMS Film Club for the past two years.

Unbridled is the story of a Mustang training and rescue facility located in Allendale that also serves as a wellness center for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). In the film, the student directors feature Unbridled Heroes Project founders, Amy and Mark Steppe, who share their incredible story of healing for both the horses and the veterans.

Congratulations on this incredible achievement! We are so proud.

To read the press release, go to https://tinyurl.com/ydbe99kh

To view the film, visit https://thebasie.org/filmfest/

Ridgewood Public Schools is incredibly proud to have been awarded the 2020 Best Communities for Music Education designation by The NAMM Foundation for its outstanding achievement in efforts to provide music access and education to all students.

“We are fortunate and proud to have a robust and competitive music education program with curricular offerings in band, orchestra and choir from grade 5 through grade 12, as well as a host of co-curricular ensembles, choral groups, an award-winning marching band, and a music production club. We believe that music adds tremendous value to a student’s educational experience, teaching them to be great listeners, leaders and teammates,” said Dr. Daniel Fishbein, Superintendent of Schools. “As a community with a long-standing history of support for the arts, this designation is a testament to the significance of music education to the families in Ridgewood.”

To read the full press release, please go to the district news at www.ridgewood.k12.nj.us.

RHS alumna Anika Tsapatsaris visited five physics classes over the past two days to share how her high school experience has prepared her for both life and learning at Columbia University, where she is studying architecture. A former student in Ms. Shah's Physics, Engineering and Art class, Anika discussed the importance of getting comfortable with being uncomfortable. "What you are doing in Ms. Shah's class is very similar to how you will be learning in college," she said. "There is no instruction sheet. You are given a concept or a goal, and it is up to you determine the process." Anika told RHS students that thinking creatively and making mistakes are important parts of learning.

When Anika is not exploring ways to design a structure that will spark a conversation, she is fencing for both her university and for Greece. Thank you, Anika, for continuing to contribute to the RPS learning community!

#RPStraditionofexcellence #lifelonglearning #Vision2024

Important Message from Dr. Fishbein
Bergen County Mosquito Control Spraying

Dear Parents and Guardians,

Weather permitting, Bergen County Mosquito Control will be spraying early tomorrow morning, October 2, to reduce the number of nuisance and vector mosquitoes in our area. County officials feel that this spraying is a necessary intervention. They plan to be finished by 6 a.m. but have given themselves a two-hour buffer in the event of unforeseen circumstances that may arise.

I know this news is the cause of some concern. If you feel it is necessary to delay your child from coming to school tomorrow due to the timing of the spray application, please feel free to do so.

I am sorry for this delayed notification, but we were just informed of the spraying on Monday when schools were closed.

Thank you in advance for your understanding during this unusual circumstance.

Sincerely,
Daniel Fishbein, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

Ridgewood High School
September 24, 2019 at 2:45 PM ·

Congratulations to longtime RHS Girls’ Cross Country Coach Jacob Brown for being named #64 on NJ.com’s Top 99 New Jersey High School Coaches of All Time. Coach Brown guided Ridgewood track and field to 76 Bergen County Meet of Champions individual winners, 159 Bergen County group individual champions and 15 state group individual champions while leading the team to 16 Bergen County team group championships, 10 sectional team titles and 15 league team titles. In cross-country his teams won 29 state group championships, 22 sectional titles and 35 league crowns. His teams were 243-15 in dual meets, including a 22-year unbeaten streak. The track and field complex at Benjamin Franklin Middle School is named for Brown, who retired in 2015. Congratulations Coach Brown and thank you for all you did and continue to do for RHS!
#RHS #MaroonPride
